profile.name: Sergio
profile.title: Open Source Contributor - Micronaut core committer - Speaker - Technical Writer
profile.description:
My name is Sergio del Amo. I am proactive developer. I like to consider myself a [manager of one](https://signalvnoise.com/posts/1430-hire-managers-of-one).


**Open Source**
I have contributed to open-source for the past six years and am a core committer to the Grails and Micronaut frameworks. 

**Java ecosystem**
Most of my experience is in the Java ecosystems. I have experience with JVM languages such as Groovy, Kotlin, or Java, testing frameworks such as JUnit or Spock, build tools such as Gradle, and JVM frameworks such as Micronaut, Grails, and Spring Boot. 

**Public Speaking**
I have talked at conferences and user groups in Spain and internationally. 

**Technical Writer**
I have written extensive documentation and tutorials for both Grails and Micronaut frameworks.

**Consultancy**
Before working on open-source, I co-founded a startup and had a small consultancy company building for clients Webs, web applications, and mobile applications - both in Android and IOS. I have experience dealing with clients and proposing solutions to their needs and budgets.

roles.name: Micronaut Product Development Lead / Distinguished Engineer

challenges.description:
In February 2023, the Micronaut Foundation joined the Unity Foundation. I joined Unity Foundation following the framework. I continued my role in the Micronaut Foundation as the developer lead and as a member of the Micronaut Foundation's board of directors. 

In 2024, the Micronaut Foundation released the fourth major version of the framework—Micronaut 4.0. I managed the release, contributing to both the technical and advocacy sides. I also coordinated the work between the Micronaut Foundation and the Oracle Labs team—both companies were the top technical contributors to the framework.  

At the Micronaut Foundation, I lead a remote team of four engineers. 

During this phase, I continued managing the framework releases, writing technical documentation, contributing bug fixes and new modules to the framework, speaking at conferences and user groups, and creating content for the framework's YouTube channel.

Promotions:
2022 March / Micronaut Development Lead
2021 October / Developer advocate for Micronaut, Grails, and Apache Groovy
2021 January / Distinguished Engineer
2020 January / Principal Software Engineer
Object Computing Inc. maintains both open-source projects, Grails (https://grails.org) and Micronaut (https://micronaut.io) frameworks.

**Grails**
During my first years at Object Computing, I helped clients migrate applications from Grails 2 to Grails 3/4. Also, I supported clients using Grails. Moreover, I worked directly in the open-source development of the Grails Framework. I contributed to the framework core code, plugins (especially security modules), and guides. I have written/reviewed almost every [Grails guide](https://guides.grails.org). 

**Micronaut**
I got involved with the Micronaut framework since its inception in 2018, and my work shifted from Grails to Micronaut.

In March 2022, I became a member of the Micronaut Foundation Board Of Directors and Micronaut Development Lead at Object Computing. I managed the framework releases and schedule and helped coordinate the collaboration of the Oracle Labs and Object Computing teams.
My most significant areas of contribution to the framework were: 

I wrote/reviewed most of the Micronaut Guides (https://guides.micronaut.io)
 I reviewed PRs (pull requests) and release modules and contributed code to the framework. 
I did a lot of the development of the modules: Security, AWS, Views, RSS, Problem+JSON, Email, Microstream, Chatbots, and Multi-tenancy. 
I did talks at conferences, meetups, and online webinars about the Micronaut framework. 
I searched for sponsors for the Micronaut Foundation and helped with partners.

Architected and developed the start-up product.

A mobile app (iOS, Android) powered by a Grails 3 backend.

Daily Tasks: Grails 3, iOS, Android, Geb Scraping, Web Design, Scripting..
Founded and managed a software company, developing websites, online shops and mobile phone apps (iOS & Android) for private companies and local government organizations.

details.name: Micronaut Guides
details.description:
Micronaut Guides are step-by-step tutorials that serve not just as documentation for the community but as a massive test suite for the framework. Every tutorial contains a sample project which users can download and run. The code snippets in those tutorials come from a real tested code. We build and run the tests in every tutorial for every Micronaut release. 

I have written or reviewed almost every guide. 

We engineered the [build](https://github.com/micronaut-projects/micronaut-guides) to minimize the update burden. Updating every tutorial to a new Micronaut version often requires just a single line of code change.

details.description: Throughout the years, I contributed a lot in the [Security](https://micronaut-projects.github.io/micronaut-security/latest/guide/index.html), [AWS](https://micronaut-projects.github.io/micronaut-aws/latest/guide/index.html), [Views](https://micronaut-projects.github.io/micronaut-views/latest/guide/index.html), [RSS](https://micronaut-projects.github.io/micronaut-rss/latest/guide/index.html), [Problem+JSON](https://micronaut-projects.github.io/micronaut-problem-json/latest/guide/index.html), [Email](https://micronaut-projects.github.io/micronaut-email/latest/guide/index.html), [Starter](https://micronaut-projects.github.io/micronaut-starter/latest/guide/index.html), [EclipseStore](https://micronaut-projects.github.io/micronaut-eclipsestore/latest/guide/index.html), [MicroStream](https://micronaut-projects.github.io/micronaut-microstream/latest/guide/index.html), [OpenSearch](https://micronaut-projects.github.io/micronaut-opensearch/latest/guide/index.html), [Multi-tenancy](https://micronaut-projects.github.io/micronaut-multitenancy/latest/guide/index.html), and [Chatbots](https://micronaut-projects.github.io/micronaut-chatbots/latest/guide/index.html) modules.

details.name: Promotion to Distinguished Engineer
details.description:
I got promoted to Distinguished Engineer in January 2022.

> OCI recognizes individuals who have demonstrated subject matter expertise in one or more technology areas, and who serve as an organizational and community thought leader and champion, as “Distinguished Engineer”.

A Distinguished engineer:

> - Demonstrates subject matter expertise in specific technology area(s)
> - Applies expertise to create novel approaches to problems
> - Stays current with evolutions in the specific technology area(s) and/or emerging related technologies
> - Are Capable of communicating, sharing, consulting, on the subject matter, serving as a consultant/leader within OCI and with our clients and community
> - Shares expertise with others both inside and outside of OCI in the forms of mentoring, screencasts, user group and conference presentations, and writing
> - Provides significant contributions to related open source software
> - Brings name recognition to OCI through involvement in user groups, conferences, standards bodies, or similar

manfredSpecificData.desiredJobDescription:
Honestly, my current job is amazing. I don't see myself changing soon. I work on Open Source. I have public recognition. I work on Micronaut - an exciting JVM framework. I have barely no deadlines. I can do different things (which suites me) from writing code, to writing documentation, do podcasts, public speaking, training. The job is flexible in terms of working hours. I can adjust my job around my kids schedule. 

However, an unfulfilled dream for me is to release a Software a Service application. Design it, code it, control every decision around it. Basecamp (37 Signals) have always been an inspiration to me.

Working for Apple would another dream
